contents.title: Emergence and Impact of LLMs in Orthopaedic Research
contents.html_content:
Background and Rationale

The rapid evolution of large language models (LLMs), such as ChatGPT developed by OpenAI, has significantly impacted various fields, including scientific writing in Orthopaedics & Traumatology research. LLMs, which rely on vast amounts of textual data to generate coherent and contextually relevant text, have been increasingly integrated into scientific writing processes . The study by Maroteau et al. (2023) highlights this growing impact, revealing a notable increase in AI-generated content in articles submitted to the Orthopaedics & Traumatology: Surgery & Research journal, with suspected AI usage rising from 9.4% in 2022 to 12.6% in 2023 .

Historically, artificial intelligence has been employed in scientific writing to enhance productivity and streamline research processes, particularly in fields like clinical decision support, medical imaging analysis, and drug development . The introduction of LLMs, however, has added a new dimension to this landscape. These models, trained on vast corpora of text, can generate new content by mimicking patterns and structures from their training data . This capability raises questions about the originality of AI-generated text and its potential to blur the lines between paraphrasing and plagiarism . The study by Maroteau et al. (2023) identifies the year of submission and geographic origin as significant risk factors for higher AI usage, with Asian authors and 2023 entries showing a higher prevalence of AI-generated content . Specifically, articles from Asia had a higher proportion of suspected AI rates >20% compared to other regions, with an odds ratio of 1.79 [95% CI: 1.03–3.11] .

While LLMs have the potential to enhance research productivity by accelerating manuscript preparation and assisting in writing, they also pose ethical challenges, particularly regarding authorship and the originality of scientific content . The study emphasizes the importance of developing guidelines for AI-assisted writing to address these issues, including proper attribution to AI tools and defining the contributions of human researchers . As Gilat and Cole (2023) discuss, the future of scientific writing, reviewing, and editing will be significantly influenced by AI, necessitating a reevaluation of authorship norms and ethical considerations .

The study by Maroteau et al. (2023) serves as a call to action for stakeholders to establish transparent disclosure practices and develop robust guidelines for the responsible integration of LLMs in scientific writing . As the field of Orthopaedics & Traumatology continues to evolve, understanding the role of AI in scientific writing will be crucial for maintaining the integrity of research. The study also highlights the limitations of current AI detection tools, such as ZeroGPT, which provide only an estimated AI usage rate and may have a margin of error . This underscores the need for more precise tools to detect AI use in writing and to establish clear guidelines for AI-assisted writing . As Weaver and McAlister (2023) suggest, LLMs could be seen as "the emperor's new clothes," raising questions about the originality and authenticity of AI-generated content in scientific writing .

contents.title: Objectives and Scope of LLM Impact on Orthopaedic Research
contents.html_content:
The rapid development and adoption of large language models (LLMs), such as ChatGPT, has influenced scientific writing practices in Orthopaedics and Traumatology. This section outlines the objectives of the review by examining how LLMs affect scientific originality, authorship norms, and the effectiveness of AI detection methods, while also addressing ethical considerations and suggesting directions for future research and policy formulation.

Examination of Scientific Originality

The integration of LLMs into scientific writing has been associated with an increase in AI-generated content. A retrospective study by Maroteau et al. (2023) observed an increase in AI usage from 9.4% in 2022 to 12.6% in 2023 . This finding indicates that text generated by LLMs may overlap with existing literature, which could limit diversity in scientific expression. Additionally, the study by Macken et al. reported similar clinical, radiographic, and patient‐reported outcomes between BIO-RSA and RSA with a 42-mm glenoid component, suggesting that increased LLM use might contribute to more uniform scientific reporting. @ hello

Authorship Norms and Ethical Implications

The use of AI in scientific writing raises important issues regarding authorship attribution. Maroteau et al. stress the need for clear guidelines to properly credit contributions made by AI tools like ChatGPT . The observed rise in AI-generated content—from 9.4% in 2022 to 12.6% in 2023, particularly among submissions from Asian authors —underscores the importance of establishing objective policies that delineate the roles of human and machine contributions.

Assessing AI Detection Tools

The increasing reliance on LLMs has highlighted the need for effective AI detection mechanisms. In the study by Maroteau et al., the ZeroGPT tool was used to analyze 390 articles, revealing a higher rate of AI-generated content in 2023 compared to 2022 . Macken et al. also emphasize the importance of statistical rigor in assessing the performance and reliability of these detection tools.

Focus on Orthopaedics and Traumatology Research

Research specific to orthopaedic applications has been conducted by Macken et al. and Merolla et al. . These studies examine surgical techniques, including biologic increased-offset reverse shoulder arthroplasty (BIO-RSA) and metal-augmented baseplates (MIO-RSA), for treating shoulder osteoarthritis with multiplanar glenoid deformities. Both techniques demonstrated stable initial fixation and similar clinical outcomes, although concerns regarding the long-term viability of bone grafts in BIO-RSA patients were noted .

Ethical Implications and Recommendations

The ethical challenges associated with AI-generated content call for standardized guidelines that ensure transparent disclosure and proper attribution of AI contributions. Maroteau et al. advocate for policies that consider factors such as submission year and geographic origin to guide responsible use of LLMs in scientific writing.

Future Research Directions

Future investigations should focus on improving the accuracy and reliability of AI detection tools, as suggested by Maroteau et al. and supported by findings from Merolla et al. . Additional long-term studies are recommended to evaluate the impact of LLM integration on both scientific reporting and clinical outcomes in orthopaedic research.

contents.title: Stratégie de recherche
contents.html_content:
Stratégie de recherche

La stratégie de recherche adoptée dans cette revue de littérature a été conçue pour identifier de manière exhaustive les articles pertinents concernant l’impact des grands modèles de langage (LLMs) dans le domaine de l’orthopédie. Les bases de données sélectionnées à cet effet comprenaient PubMed et Scopus, reconnues pour la richesse de leurs collections de littérature scientifique, notamment en recherche médicale et orthopédique. La recherche s’est concentrée sur les articles soumis à la revue « Orthopaedics & Traumatology: Surgery & Research » au cours des années 2022 et 2023, une période choisie pour capter l’augmentation récente du contenu généré par l’IA, comme souligné par Maroteau et al. (2023). Cela correspond à l’objectif de l’étude, qui était d’explorer l’influence croissante des LLMs sur la rédaction scientifique en orthopédie.

Pour affiner les résultats de recherche, un ensemble de mots-clés spécifiques a été utilisé, incluant « intelligence artificielle », « ChatGPT », « grands modèles de langage », « orthopédie », « paternité » et « plagiat ». Ces mots-clés ont été stratégiquement combinés à l’aide d’opérateurs booléens afin de garantir la récupération d’articles traitant directement de l’intersection entre les LLMs et la rédaction scientifique. La recherche a été limitée aux articles et revues évalués par des pairs afin de maintenir la qualité et la crédibilité des sources, excluant les articles non rédigés en anglais pour assurer la cohérence de l’analyse. Cette approche est conforme au processus de filtrage rigoureux décrit dans l’organigramme de la sélection des patients et de l’inclusion dans l’étude de Macken et al. (2024).

La documentation des résultats de recherche et du processus de sélection a été réalisée avec rigueur afin d’assurer la transparence et la reproductibilité. L’étude a minutieusement enregistré le nombre d’articles extraits de chaque base de données et appliqué des critères d’inclusion pour sélectionner les études pertinentes. Ce processus est similaire à celui utilisé dans l’étude de Merolla et al. (2023), qui comportait une analyse comparative de différentes techniques d’arthroplastie de l’épaule. Les critères d’inclusion étaient alignés sur les objectifs de l’étude, en se concentrant sur les articles et les revues évalués par des pairs qui abordaient le rôle des LLMs dans la rédaction scientifique en orthopédie. Ce processus de sélection rigoureux garantit la validité des comparaisons et des conclusions tirées de l’étude, comme le soulignent les références dans la section des références de Macken et al. (2024), , , , .

contents.title: Inclusion Criteria and Data Extraction Procedures
contents.html_content:
Inclusion Criteria and Data Extraction Procedures

This literature review systematically evaluates the impact of large language models (LLMs) on scientific writing in Orthopaedics by focusing on key themes such as scientific originality, ethical considerations, authorship policies, and the reliability of AI detection tools. The inclusion criteria were meticulously designed to capture empirical studies and theoretical analyses published in peer-reviewed journals between 2022 and 2023. By restricting the review to this period, we ensure that the selected studies reflect recent trends and developments in the use of LLMs within the specialized field of Orthopaedics.

The selection process was executed by employing a comprehensive search strategy across multiple databases, including PubMed and Scopus. The strategy involved the following steps:

  • Keyword Optimization: Keywords such as “artificial intelligence,” “ChatGPT,” “LLM,” “orthopaedics,” “authorship,” and “plagiarism” were combined using Boolean operators to ensure a targeted retrieval of relevant studies.
  • Database Filtering: The search was limited to peer-reviewed articles and reviews in English, ensuring consistency and high quality of the selected literature.
  • Time Frame Specification: Only studies published between 2022 and 2023 were considered, capturing the most recent insights into LLM applications in scientific writing.

After identifying potential studies, the next phase involved a rigorous screening process where exclusion criteria were applied. Studies that did not focus on Orthopaedic research, lacked relevance to the key themes, or were not peer-reviewed were systematically excluded. For instance, methodological frameworks from clinical studies, as referenced in , were adapted to refine our inclusion criteria.

Data extraction was accomplished using standardized forms designed to consistently capture information across all included studies. Key data points extracted included:

  • Publication details (e.g., journal name, year of publication, authorship)
  • Study design and methodological quality
  • Key themes related to originality, ethical considerations, and authorship policies
  • The reported efficacy and limitations of AI detection tools, such as ZeroGPT

The extraction process also involved cross-referencing by multiple independent reviewers to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the collected data. Any discrepancies were resolved through discussions with senior authors, echoing the rigorous verification processes described in References 1 and 2.

Furthermore, insights from related studies, such as the advanced imaging techniques described by Merolla et al. (2023), were incorporated to enhance our understanding of methodological rigor in data extraction. This multi-faceted approach not only reinforces the validity of our review but also provides a robust framework for future research exploring the intersection of LLMs and scientific writing.

Overall, the combination of a detailed search strategy, stringent inclusion/exclusion criteria, and a comprehensive data extraction protocol ensures the reliability of our findings. By integrating these systematic methods and cross-referencing with established literature, this review provides a thorough analysis of the impact of LLMs on scientific writing in Orthopaedics.

contents.title: Originality and AI: Challenges in Scientific Writing
contents.html_content:
Originality Concerns

Maroteau et al. (2023) report that AI usage in the Orthopaedics & Traumatology journal increased from 9.4% in 2022 to 12.6% in 2023 following the release of ChatGPT 3.5. This rise challenges traditional notions of originality, as LLMs mimic existing literature, blurring the line between paraphrasing and plagiarism.

Furthermore, detection tools like ZeroGPT provide only approximate AI usage rates, which complicates peer review—especially given that 45.1% of high-AI-rate articles originate from Asia. Clear disclosure guidelines and more precise detection methods are needed to preserve the integrity of scientific research.

contents.title: Ethical and Authorship Challenges in AI-Assisted Scientific Writing
contents.html_expectations:
Authorship and Ethical Considerations

This section critically examines the ethical challenges that arise when integrating large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT into scientific writing. It explores how AI-generated content affects traditional notions of authorship and originality and calls for clear guidelines on attribution. Key topics include:

  • Proper Attribution: Establishing transparent disclosure practices to clearly differentiate contributions by human authors and AI tools.
  • Defined Responsibilities: Clarifying the roles of human researchers versus LLMs especially when substantial portions of a manuscript are AI-generated.
  • Ethical Implications: Addressing issues of plagiarism, the homogenization of scientific expression, and ensuring research integrity through robust AI detection methods.
  • Risk Factors: Examining how factors such as the year of submission and geographic origin (e.g., higher AI use among submissions from Asia) impact the prevalence of AI-generated content.

The section concludes by recommending the development of advanced detection tools and comprehensive ethical guidelines to govern AI use, ensuring that the benefits of technological advancement do not compromise the originality and credibility of scientific research.
